The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test refers to the probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease. On the other hand, the negative predictive value (NPV) refers to the probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don't have the disease.  If the threshold for recommending a biopsy procedure were lowered to 2.0 ng/mL, more men would test positive for prostate cancer, including those who do not actually have the disease (false positives). This would decrease the positive predictive value of the test because the proportion of true positives (men who test positive and actually have the disease) to total positives (men who test positive, whether they have the disease or not) would decrease.  Conversely, the negative predictive value would increase. This is because fewer men would test negative for prostate cancer, and a larger proportion of these would truly not have the disease (true negatives). The proportion of true negatives to total negatives (men who test negative, whether they have the disease or not) would increase, thus increasing the negative predictive value.   However, it's important to note that while the NPV increases, the risk of missing a cancer diagnosis (false negatives) also increases. This is a significant consideration in determining the appropriate threshold for recommending a biopsy.

The woman's physical state at the end of the race will most likely activate the renal segments responsible for water reabsorption, which are the proximal convoluted tubule and the collecting ducts. Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. It works by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor and also stimulates the release of aldosterone, which leads to sodium and water retention. By inhibiting the formation of angiotensin II, ACE inhibitors like lisinopril cause vasodilation and reduce fluid volume, which helps to lower blood pressure.  In the kidneys, angiotensin II preferentially constricts the efferent arterioles (the blood vessels leading out of the glomeruli). This increases the pressure in the glomeruli, which can lead to proteinuria (protein in the urine), a common complication of diabetes and hypertension. By blocking the formation of angiotensin II, lisinopril reduces the pressure in the glomeruli, which can help to reduce proteinuria.  Therefore, the most likely changes in glomerular hemodynamics in this patient as a result of lisinopril therapy would be a decrease in glomerular pressure and a decrease in proteinuria.

This newborn is most likely to show a deficiency of the enzyme 21-hydroxylase.   The ambiguous genitalia in a 46,XX newborn, along with markedly increased serum concentrations of 17-hydroxyprogesterone, suggest the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The block in cortisol synthesis leads to increased ACTH secretion due to lack of negative feedback, which in turn causes adrenal hyperplasia and overproduction of cortisol precursors. These precursors are shunted into the androgen synthesis pathway, leading to virilization. In 46,XX individuals, this can result in ambiguous genitalia.

The most likely cause of the fracture in this patient is an increase in glucocorticoid production and osteoclastic bone resorption.  The patient's presentation and laboratory results are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome, a condition characterized by excessive cortisol production. This can be due to various causes, including an adrenal tumor, pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease), or ectopic ACTH production. Symptoms and signs include central obesity, purple striae, thin extremities, and hypertension, all of which are present in this patient.  Excessive glucocorticoids have several effects on bone. They increase osteoclast activity, leading to increased bone resorption. They also decrease osteoblast activity, leading to decreased bone formation. Additionally, they impair calcium absorption in the gut and increase renal calcium excretion, leading to a negative calcium balance. These effects result in a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of fractures. In this patient, the spontaneous vertebral fracture is likely due to these effects of excessive cortisol on bone.

The most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms is postpartum thyroiditis. Postpartum thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition that occurs in the first year after delivery in up to 10% of women. It is characterized by an initial, transient thyrotoxic phase that occurs 1-6 months postpartum, followed by a hypothyroid phase that occurs approximately 4-8 months postpartum. The thyroid gland is typically enlarged and non-tender, and there is no exophthalmos. The diagnosis is confirmed by low TSH and high free T4 and T3 levels. The condition is usually self-limiting, but some women may develop permanent hypothyroidism.

The most likely diagnosis is uterine prolapse.   Uterine prolapse occurs when pelvic floor muscles and ligaments stretch and weaken, providing inadequate support for the uterus. The uterus then descends into the vaginal canal. This condition is more common in postmenopausal women who have had one or more vaginal deliveries. Risk factors include advanced age, multiparity, obesity, and anything that increases intra-abdominal pressure (eg, chronic cough, constipation).   Symptoms of uterine prolapse include a sensation of heaviness or pulling in the pelvis, tissue protruding from the vagina, urinary problems (eg, incontinence, retention), and sexual concerns (eg, sensation of looseness in the tone of vaginal tissue). In severe cases, the uterus may be seen at the vaginal introitus or may even protrude outside the vagina, as in this patient.   Uterine prolapse can also cause kinking of the ureters, leading to urinary retention, which can be relieved by manually repositioning the uterus, as in this patient.

Given the high mortality rate, empiric antibiotic therapy covering encapsulated organisms should be initiated immediately in any febrile asplenic patient while diagnostic workup (eg, blood cultures, chest x-ray) is underway.

The most appropriate initial step in management is to provide sleep hygiene education. This patient's symptoms of difficulty falling asleep, waking up after 1-2 hours of sleep and not being able to fall back asleep, and not feeling rested in the morning are consistent with insomnia. If these interventions do not improve her symptoms, further evaluation and potential pharmacologic treatment may be necessary.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform a neuropsychological testing. The most appropriate next step in management is to rewarm the patient's feet. This woman's presentation is consistent with frostbite, which occurs when tissues freeze after exposure to cold temperatures. Symptoms include coldness and pain in the affected area, followed by numbness, and changes in skin color, usually to a pale or bluish hue. The primary treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming of the affected area, typically in a water bath with a temperature of 37-39°C (98.6-102.2°F). This should be done as soon as possible to prevent further tissue damage. Pain medication may also be needed, as the rewarming process can be painful.

The most appropriate next step in management is to administer platelet transfusion. The most likely diagnosis for this 13-year-old boy is myocarditis. Myocarditis is an inflammation of the heart muscle, often caused by a viral infection. The boy's recent symptoms of rhinorrhea, cough, and sore throat suggest a recent viral infection, which could have spread to his heart. The most likely diagnosis for this newborn is intestinal obstruction, specifically malrotation with midgut volvulus. This condition is a congenital anomaly in which the intestines do not rotate properly during fetal development, leading to a narrow base of mesenteric attachment that can twist (volvulus), causing obstruction and possible ischemia. The classic presentation is bilious vomiting in a newborn within the first month of life. The child may also present with abdominal distension and tenderness, as in this case. This is a surgical emergency because of the risk of bowel necrosis.

The patient's serum glucose concentration is 44 mg/dL, which is significantly lower than the normal range of 70-100 mg/dL. The most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion.   Testicular torsion is a condition in which the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This twisting cuts off the testicle's blood supply and causes sudden, severe pain and swelling. Testicular torsion is most common in males aged 12-18 years old.   The symptoms described by the boy, such as severe scrotal pain, edema, and tenderness, are typical of testicular torsion. The absence of the cremasteric reflex on the right side is also a strong indicator of this condition. The cremasteric reflex is a superficial reflex found in human males that is elicited when the inner part of the thigh is stroked, causing the testicle on the same side to move upward; the absence of this reflex is a sign of testicular torsion.   The fact that the left testicle is lower than the right one could be a normal anatomical variation, but in this context, it could also suggest that the right testicle is elevated due to the torsion.   Testicular torsion is a medical emergency. If not treated promptly, it can lead to loss of the testicle. Therefore, any male with sudden onset of severe testicular pain should seek immediate medical attention.

The most appropriate initial step in diagnosis would be the measurement of creatine kinase (CK) levels.   The patient's symptoms of muscle pain and weakness, in conjunction with his recent initiation of atorvastatin therapy, suggest the possibility of statin-induced myopathy. Statins, such as atorvastatin, are commonly used to lower cholesterol levels but can cause muscle-related side effects in some patients. These side effects can range from mild muscle pain to a more serious condition called rhabdomyolysis, which involves muscle breakdown and can lead to kidney damage.   Creatine kinase is an enzyme found in the heart, brain, and skeletal muscles. When there is muscle damage, CK leaks into the blood, so elevated levels can indicate a muscle disorder such as statin-induced myopathy. Therefore, measuring CK levels would be a useful initial step in diagnosing this patient's condition.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to start the patient on a second-generation antipsychotic medication.   This patient's profound sadness, decreased interest in activities, insomnia, decreased appetite, and feelings of worthlessness are consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD). Antidepressants alone (eg, fluoxetine) are not sufficient treatment and may even worsen psychosis. Instead, the first-line treatment for psychotic depression is a combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer vasopressors.   The patient's clinical presentation and history of septic shock due to pneumonia, along with the steadily decreasing blood pressure despite fluid resuscitation, suggest that he is in septic shock. Septic shock is defined as sepsis-induced hypotension that persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation. In this case, the patient has received 4 L of 0.9% saline but his blood pressure remains low (79/43 mm Hg), indicating that the shock state persists.   The use of vasopressors, such as norepinephrine, is indicated in patients with septic shock when hypotension persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation. Vasopressors work by constricting blood vessels, which increases vascular resistance and subsequently raises blood pressure. This helps to maintain adequate perfusion to vital organs.   The patient's decreasing lactic acid levels suggest that tissue perfusion is improving, but the persistently low blood pressure indicates that further intervention is needed. Therefore, the initiation of vasopressor therapy is the most appropriate next step in management.

The most likely diagnosis for this 7-year-old boy is dyslexia.   Dyslexia is a learning disorder that involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words (decoding). This condition is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities. These difficulties typically result from a deficit in the phonological component of language that is often unexpected in relation to other cognitive abilities and the provision of effective classroom instruction.   In this case, the boy's difficulty in sounding out unfamiliar words, despite normal speech fluency, articulation, motor skills, visual acuity, and hearing, suggests a problem with phonological processing, which is a key characteristic of dyslexia. His poor performance in school and frustration with his progress also align with this diagnosis. Despite being bright and motivated, children with dyslexia often struggle academically due to their reading difficulties.

The most likely diagnosis for this patient is otitis externa, also known as swimmer's ear. This condition is an infection of the outer ear canal, which runs from your eardrum to the outside of your head. It's often caused by water that remains in your ear after swimming, creating a moist environment that aids bacterial growth. However, it can also be caused by damaging the skin in the ear canal through actions such as using earplugs or headphones. Symptoms include itchiness, redness, swelling (edema), and pain when the ear is pulled or touched. The presence of cerumen (earwax) can also indicate otitis externa, as the infection can cause an increase in earwax production.

This condition is often associated with VATER syndrome, a non-random association of birth defects which includes vertebral defects, anal atresia, tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia, and radial and renal dysplasia. The "scooping" on the expiratory limb of the flow volume loop is indicative of variable intrathoracic airway obstruction, which is consistent with tracheomalacia. The harsh vibratory sound heard on examination could be stridor, also suggestive of an airway obstruction.

The best study to confirm this diagnosis would be Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the brain and spinal cord with gadolinium contrast. This can reveal multiple areas of demyelination (plaques) in different stages of evolution, which is characteristic of MS. Additionally, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showing oligoclonal bands can also support the diagnosis.

The patient's presentation is consistent with serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition caused by an excess of serotonin in the brain. It is most often caused by the use of certain drugs, including the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) that this patient is taking. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and include agitation, restlessness, confusion, rapid heart rate, dilated pupils, loss of muscle coordination, heavy sweating, diarrhea, headache, shivering, and goosebumps.  In terms of pharmacotherapy, the first step would be to discontinue the offending medications, in this case, the paroxetine and duloxetine. Supportive care, including hydration and control of agitation, may be sufficient for mild cases. However, for moderate to severe cases like this one, a serotonin antagonist such as cyproheptadine may be administered. Cyproheptadine is an H1 antihistamine with additional anticholinergic and antiserotonergic properties, making it effective in treating serotonin syndrome.   In addition, the patient's vital signs should be closely monitored and any abnormalities corrected. For example, if the patient's high blood pressure and heart rate do not improve after discontinuation of the SSRIs and SNRIs, antihypertensive and/or beta-blocker medications may be needed.   Finally, once the patient's condition has stabilized, a reassessment of his depression treatment will be necessary. It may be appropriate to consider other classes of antidepressants or non-pharmacological treatments such as psychotherapy or electroconvulsive therapy.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to refer this patient to a psychiatrist.   This patient's statements and behavior suggest a possible delusional disorder, which is characterized by one or more delusions for a duration of one month or longer, without the occurrence of active phase symptoms of schizophrenia (eg, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior). The delusions are often persecutory or grandiose, and the patient's affect and behavior are otherwise normal. This patient's belief that drug dealers are after him and that the office staff are making derogatory remarks about him are examples of persecutory delusions. His belief that doctors and drug companies are conspiring to take his money is a grandiose delusion.   Given the chronicity of his symptoms (ie, 7 years), schizophrenia is less likely because his affect and behavior are not disorganized, and he does not have hallucinations. A referral to psychiatry is indicated for further evaluation and management.

The most likely explanation for these findings is vulvar cancer. The patient's age, history of cervical dysplasia, and the presence of a large verrucous lesion on the perineum are all suggestive of this diagnosis. Vulvar cancer is most common in older women and often presents with symptoms such as bleeding, pruritus, or a mass. The lesion described in this case is typical of vulvar cancer, which can appear as a lump, ulcer, or wart-like growth. The atrophic changes seen on speculum examination are likely due to age-related changes and do not necessarily indicate malignancy. However, any postmenopausal woman with unexplained vaginal bleeding should be evaluated for malignancy.

The most appropriate initial step in management is to perform a fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy.  A nodule in the thyroid gland can be a sign of a benign or malignant condition. The majority of thyroid nodules are benign, but it's important to rule out malignancy. The best way to do this is through a fine-needle aspiration biopsy, which involves using a thin needle to remove a small sample of tissue from the nodule. This sample can then be examined under a microscope to determine whether it's benign or malignant.   The patient's normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels suggest that the nodule is not causing hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, but this doesn't rule out the possibility of cancer. Therefore, a biopsy is still necessary.   If the FNA biopsy results are benign, the patient can be monitored with periodic ultrasounds. If the results are malignant or suspicious, the patient may need surgery to remove the nodule or the entire thyroid gland.

The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this newborn is oral zidovudine (AZT) for 6 weeks.  The mother's HIV infection puts the newborn at risk of perinatal HIV transmission. However, the risk of transmission is significantly reduced by the mother's use of antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, her low HIV viral load, and the administration of intravenous zidovudine during labor. Despite these measures, postnatal antiretroviral prophylaxis is recommended for all infants born to HIV-infected mothers to further reduce the risk of transmission. The standard regimen is oral zidovudine, started within 6-12 hours of birth and continued for 6 weeks. This regimen has been shown to reduce the risk of perinatal HIV transmission by approximately two-thirds.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to refer the patient to a neurosurgeon for evaluation and possible surgical removal of the pituitary mass.  The patient's symptoms of amenorrhea (absence of menstruation) and galactorrhea (milky nipple discharge), along with the elevated prolactin level, suggest a prolactinoma, which is a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that overproduces prolactin. The bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes) and the MRI findings indicate that the tumor is large (macroadenoma) and is compressing the optic chiasm, which can lead to vision loss if not treated.   While medication (dopamine agonists) is usually the first line of treatment for prolactinomas, surgery is considered when there is a threat to vision, as in this case. Therefore, referral to a neurosurgeon is the most appropriate next step.

The most likely test to confirm the diagnosis in this case would be an abdominal radiograph. The symptoms described, such as temperature instability, decreased activity, gastric residue in the orogastric tube, mild abdominal distension, tenderness, decreased bowel sounds, and blood-streaked stool, are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a serious intestinal disease common in premature infants. An abdominal radiograph can show signs of NEC such as pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal venous gas, or even perforation.

The most accurate characterization of this patient's pattern of care is "fragmented care." Fragmented care refers to a situation where a patient's healthcare is divided among multiple providers or facilities, often without proper coordination or communication between them. This can lead to inefficiencies, repeated tests, and potential for errors or missed diagnoses. In this case, the patient was seen at three different hospitals before receiving the necessary treatment.

The most likely way to confirm this patient's diagnosis would be through an electroencephalogram (EEG). An EEG is a test that detects electrical activity in the brain using small, flat metal discs (electrodes) attached to the scalp. This test is commonly used to diagnose epilepsy and other seizure disorders. In this case, the patient's history of a seizure disorder and the recent episode of prolonged seizure activity suggest that her condition may have changed or worsened, which would be reflected in the EEG results.

The most appropriate next step in management is to provide analgesics for pain relief and reassure the patient.   The patient's symptoms are suggestive of pleuritic chest pain, which is characterized by sharp, severe pain that worsens with coughing, sneezing, or deep breathing. This is due to inflammation of the pleura, the lining of the lungs and chest cavity. The recent history of upper respiratory tract infection suggests that this is likely viral pleurisy, a common cause of pleuritic chest pain.   Viral pleurisy is typically self-limited and resolves within a few days to a week. Treatment is primarily supportive, focusing on pain management with analgesics such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Reassurance is also important, as the severe pain can cause significant distress but does not indicate a serious or life-threatening condition.   The patient's history of recurrent aphthous ulcers and use of oral contraceptives are not directly related to her current symptoms. The normal findings on physical examination and chest x-ray further support the diagnosis of viral pleurisy and rule out other causes of chest pain such as pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or cardiac conditions.

The most likely cause of this patient's amenorrhea is functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA). FHA is a form of chronic anovulation, not due to identifiable organic causes, but often associated with stress, weight loss, excessive exercise, or a combination thereof. In this case, the patient's recent deployment and work as an army combat medic could have been a significant source of stress, leading to FHA. The normal physical examination and normal laboratory values (including negative pregnancy test) further support a diagnosis of FHA, as other causes of amenorrhea (such as thyroid disease, hyperprolactinemia, or ovarian failure) would typically present with abnormal findings in these areas.

The serum concentrations of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Estradiol are most likely to confirm the diagnosis.   This woman's age and the absence of menses for 1 year are suggestive of menopause. Menopause is diagnosed clinically in women over age 45 who have experienced 12 consecutive months of amenorrhea without other obvious pathological or physiological cause. It represents the end of a woman's reproductive lifespan and is confirmed by elevated FSH levels (>30 IU/L) and low estradiol levels. FSH levels rise because the ovarian follicles are no longer responsive to FSH stimulation and thus do not produce enough estradiol to exert negative feedback on the pituitary.

The most appropriate measure to prevent complications in this patient is to provide pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and meningococcal vaccinations, and to consider prophylactic penicillin therapy.  The patient's newborn screening result showing hemoglobin FS is indicative of sickle cell disease. This is a genetic disorder that affects the structure of the hemoglobin, causing it to form a sickle or crescent shape. This can lead to various complications, including infections, as the spleen, which helps filter bacteria from the bloodstream, is often damaged in sickle cell disease.  Pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and meningococcal vaccinations are recommended for these patients because they are at increased risk for invasive infections by encapsulated organisms due to functional asplenia. Prophylactic penicillin therapy is also recommended from diagnosis (usually from the newborn period) until at least age 5 years to prevent pneumococcal infection.   In addition to these measures, parents should be educated about the signs of infection (eg, fever, lethargy, poor feeding) and the importance of seeking immediate medical attention if these occur.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform an abdominal ultrasound.   The patient's symptoms of jaundice, white stools, and enlarged liver and spleen, along with the laboratory findings of elevated bilirubin and liver enzymes, suggest a diagnosis of biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a serious liver disorder that occurs in infants, where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, leading to liver damage. An abdominal ultrasound can help visualize the liver and bile ducts, and is often the first imaging test done when biliary atresia is suspected. If the ultrasound findings are suggestive of biliary atresia, further confirmatory tests such as a liver biopsy or a special procedure called a cholangiogram may be performed.

The most appropriate next step in management of this patient's cough would be to switch her antihypertensive medication from lisinopril to another drug.   Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, which is commonly used to treat hypertension. However, a common side effect of ACE inhibitors is a persistent, dry cough. This is due to the accumulation of bradykinin, a potent vasodilator, in the respiratory tract. This side effect is not harmful, but it can be quite bothersome for some patients, as in this case.   If a patient develops a cough due to an ACE inhibitor, the best course of action is usually to switch to a different class of antihypertensive medication. An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) such as losartan or valsartan could be a good alternative, as these drugs have a similar effect on blood pressure but do not increase bradykinin levels and therefore do not cause a cough.

The most likely adverse effect of an intravenous opioid in this patient is neonatal respiratory depression. Opioids are commonly used for pain relief during labor, but they cross the placenta and can affect the fetus. If given too close to the time of delivery, they can cause respiratory depression in the newborn. This is because opioids depress the respiratory centers in the brain, reducing the response to carbon dioxide and thus decreasing the drive to breathe.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be a sleep study (polysomnography). The girl's symptoms of snoring, bedwetting, and behavioral problems, including difficulty concentrating and learning at school, suggest she may have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA is a condition where the airway becomes partially or completely blocked during sleep, leading to periods of apnea or hypopnea. This can result in fragmented sleep and lower quality of sleep overall. In children, OSA can lead to behavioral problems and learning difficulties, as well as physical symptoms like snoring and bedwetting. The girl's enlarged tonsils (3+) could be contributing to the obstruction of her airway during sleep. A sleep study would help confirm the diagnosis by monitoring her breathing, oxygen levels, and other factors during sleep.

The most appropriate action in this situation is to proceed with the transfusion of blood and plasma. This is because the child's life is in immediate danger due to severe blood loss, as indicated by his extremely low blood pressure and hemoglobin concentration. In many jurisdictions, the law allows healthcare providers to override parental refusal of life-saving treatment for a minor in emergency situations. This is based on the principle of "best interest of the child," which holds that the child's right to life and health takes precedence over parental rights and religious beliefs. The healthcare team should, however, make every effort to explain the situation to the parents and seek their understanding and consent.

The most appropriate next step in management is administration of Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1).   The clinical presentation is suggestive of congenital heart disease with ductal-dependent systemic blood flow, such as hypoplastic left heart syndrome, interrupted aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta. These conditions are characterized by obstruction to systemic blood flow, which leads to profound hypoxemia and acidosis shortly after birth when the ductus arteriosus begins to close. The ductus arteriosus is a fetal blood vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs. After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes within the first few hours to days of life. However, in conditions with obstruction to systemic blood flow, closure of the ductus arteriosus can lead to severe cyanosis and shock.   Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open, thereby improving systemic blood flow. This is a temporary measure until definitive surgical correction can be performed.

The most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prescribe at this time is a calcium channel blocker or a long-acting nitrate. The patient's symptoms and the ECG changes during the episode of chest pain are suggestive of coronary artery spasm (Prinzmetal angina). Coronary artery spasm causes transient ST-segment elevation (or, less commonly, ST-segment depression) on ECG and can occur in patients with or without significant coronary artery disease. The pain often occurs at rest and may follow a circadian pattern, with a peak incidence in the early morning hours. First-line treatment options include calcium channel blockers and long-acting nitrates. Short-acting nitrates (eg, sublingual nitroglycerin) can be used for acute relief of symptoms.

The strongest predisposing risk factor for suicide in this patient is her alcohol use disorder. Alcohol use disorder is associated with a high risk of suicide, particularly in those with a history of multiple attempts to quit drinking. This is due to the fact that alcohol can increase impulsivity, decrease judgment, and exacerbate depressive symptoms, all of which can increase the risk of suicide. Other risk factors for suicide in this patient include her history of mental health disorders (panic disorder and dependent personality disorder), lack of social support, recent job loss, and history of domestic abuse. However, her alcohol use disorder is the most significant risk factor.

The most appropriate next step in management for this patient would be to administer morphine.   This patient's labored breathing (dyspnea) and hypoxemia despite receiving 100% oxygen are indicative of end-stage lung disease. In patients with end-stage disease, the goal of care is often to maximize comfort. Opioids, such as morphine, are the treatment of choice for dyspnea in palliative care settings. They decrease the sensation of breathlessness without causing significant respiratory depression at therapeutic doses.   In addition to its analgesic effects, morphine has anxiolytic properties that can further contribute to the relief of dyspnea. It is important to start at a low dose and titrate up as needed for symptom control, monitoring for side effects such as excessive sedation and delirium.   Other interventions such as noninvasive positive pressure ventilation or intubation are unlikely to provide long-term benefit and may cause distress in this patient with terminal illness. Therefore, the focus should be on symptom management and comfort care.

This patient is most likely at risk for conditions related to Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). MEN2 is a genetic disorder that causes tumors to form in up to three different endocrine glands: the parathyroid, adrenal, and thyroid glands. Given her family history of hyperparathyroidism and adrenal tumors, as well as her own history of renal calculi and increased serum calcium concentration, it is likely that she has inherited this condition.   The high urine metanephrine concentration indicates that she may have a pheochromocytoma, a type of adrenal gland tumor that can cause high blood pressure, which could explain her labile hypertension and the arteriovenous nicking seen on funduscopic examination.   The high serum calcium concentration could be due to hyperparathyroidism, another component of MEN2, which can cause kidney stones (renal calculi), bone pain, and abdominal pain.   In addition, patients with MEN2 are at risk for medullary thyroid cancer. Therefore, this patient should be evaluated for this condition as well.

The most appropriate next step in management for this patient would be to perform a biopsy of the enlarged lymph nodes.   The patient's symptoms of night sweats, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy are concerning for lymphoma, which is a known complication of common variable immunodeficiency (CVID). CVID is a primary immunodeficiency characterized by low levels of most or all of the immunoglobulin (Ig) classes, poor response to vaccines, and susceptibility to bacterial infections. Patients with CVID are at an increased risk for autoimmune disease, granulomatous disease, and malignancy, particularly lymphoma.   Therefore, in a patient with CVID presenting with B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) and lymphadenopathy, lymphoma must be ruled out. The best way to do this is through a lymph node biopsy.

The most appropriate next step in management is to start the child on oral antibiotics. The child's symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of bullous impetigo, a superficial skin infection usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus. This condition is characterized by the presence of large, flaccid bullae filled with yellow fluid on an erythematous base. It is more common in children and can occur anywhere on the body, but is most often found in areas covered by a diaper. Treatment typically involves oral antibiotics, such as cephalexin or dicloxacillin, to cover for S. aureus. Topical antibiotics are usually not sufficient for bullous impetigo because the infection is deeper in the skin compared to non-bullous impetigo.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be an abdominal ultrasound.   The patient's presentation of severe epigastric and right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting after meals is suggestive of gallstone disease (cholelithiasis). The pain is typically postprandial, often occurs at night, and may radiate to the right scapula or shoulder. Fever and leukocytosis suggest progression to acute cholecystitis, which occurs when a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct, leading to inflammation and infection of the gallbladder.   An abdominal ultrasound is the best initial diagnostic test for suspected gallstone disease because it has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting gallstones and can also identify signs of acute cholecystitis (eg, gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid).

The most appropriate next step in management would be to provide supplemental oxygen.   This patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is characterized by chronic airflow limitation and a heightened inflammatory response in the airways. The airflow limitation is not fully reversible and usually progresses over time. The primary symptoms of COPD are dyspnea, chronic cough, and sputum production, and a history of exposure to risk factors such as smoking is typically present.   In this case, the patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia (low oxygen level in the blood) and hypercapnia (high carbon dioxide level in the blood), indicating severe COPD. The goal of oxygen therapy in COPD is to increase the patient's baseline oxygen saturation to at least 88%-92%, which has been shown to improve survival, decrease the work of breathing, and improve the mental state in hypoxemic patients with COPD.   The patient's symptoms of feeling "jittery" and having a mild tremor after the albuterol nebulizer treatment are common side effects of albuterol, which is a short-acting β2-agonist. These symptoms should resolve on their own with time.   Smoking cessation is the most effective intervention to slow the progression of COPD. Antibiotics and corticosteroids are used to treat acute exacerbations of COPD, which are often caused by respiratory infections.

This patient is at greatest risk for colorectal cancer. He has symptoms and signs suggestive of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis (UC). UC is a chronic inflammatory condition of the colon characterized by bloody diarrhea, urgency, and abdominal pain. Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include uveitis and erythema nodosum, which are both present in this patient. Patients with UC are at increased risk for colorectal cancer due to the chronic inflammation of the colon. Therefore, regular colonoscopy screenings are recommended for these patients to detect early signs of cancer.

The most likely mechanism of these laboratory findings is stress hyperglycemia.   Stress hyperglycemia is a medical term referring to transient increase in the blood glucose levels in response to certain stressful conditions such as severe illness or trauma. In this case, the patient has sustained a severe trauma from a motor vehicle collision, which has resulted in a closed head injury, liver laceration, and pelvic fracture. This severe trauma has likely triggered a stress response in the body, leading to an increase in the blood glucose levels.   The body's response to stress includes the release of stress hormones such as cortisol, adrenaline, and glucagon. These hormones stimulate the liver to produce and release more glucose into the bloodstream, leading to an increase in blood glucose levels. This is a normal response of the body to ensure that it has enough energy to deal with the stressful situation.   However, in a critical illness or severe trauma, this response can be exaggerated, leading to significantly elevated blood glucose levels, as seen in this patient. This is known as stress hyperglycemia.   The patient's other laboratory findings, such as the hematocrit and leukocyte count, are also consistent with the body's response to severe trauma. The hematocrit is low, which could be due to blood loss from the injuries, and the leukocyte count is high, which is a typical response to inflammation or infection.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to arrange for a home safety evaluation. This patient's insistence on going home despite not being fully cleared by her physical therapist and physiatrist raises the issue of patient autonomy versus medical advice. A home safety evaluation can help determine if the patient's home environment is safe for her current level of mobility. This evaluation typically includes an assessment of the patient's ability to perform activities of daily living, the need for assistive devices, and potential home modifications. If the home environment is deemed safe and the patient's family is able to provide adequate support, the patient may be able to continue her rehabilitation at home.

The most likely explanation for this patient's increased blood pressure is primary (essential) hypertension. This is a diagnosis of exclusion made when secondary causes of hypertension (eg, renal disease, endocrine disorders) have been ruled out. In this patient, normal serum creatinine and urea nitrogen levels make renal disease unlikely. The low serum potassium could suggest hyperaldosteronism, but this condition would also typically cause metabolic alkalosis, which is not present here (normal HCO₃⁻).   Primary hypertension is the most common form of hypertension, affecting about 85%-95% of patients. It is a complex, multifactorial disease thought to be influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. Risk factors include age, family history, obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), physical inactivity, tobacco use, high-sodium diet, low-potassium diet, and excessive alcohol use. This patient's BMI of 26 kg/m² places her in the overweight category, which could contribute to her hypertension.   The patient's fatigue could be related to her hypertension, as chronic high blood pressure can sometimes cause symptoms like fatigue, headaches, or dizziness. However, these symptoms are nonspecific and could be due to a variety of other causes as well.

The most likely diagnosis for this patient is necrotizing fasciitis.  Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressive infection of the subcutaneous tissue and fascia. It is often associated with systemic signs of infection such as fever and severe pain. The skin may initially appear erythematous and edematous, but as the disease progresses, it may become dusky and develop bullae, as in this patient. The presence of bullae containing thick purple fluid is particularly concerning for necrotizing infection. The infection can spread rapidly along the fascial planes, leading to extensive tissue destruction. Necrotizing fasciitis is a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention. Risk factors for necrotizing fasciitis include diabetes mellitus, as in this patient, as well as other conditions that compromise the immune system.

The most appropriate recommendation for this patient would be regular occupational health check-ups and ensuring the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) at her workplace.   Working in a paper mill factory that uses liquid chlorine can expose the worker to chlorine gas, which can cause respiratory problems and other health issues. Regular health check-ups can help in early detection of any potential health problems.   In addition, the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks, gloves, and protective clothing can significantly reduce the exposure to chlorine and other harmful substances. The patient should also be educated about the potential risks and symptoms of chlorine exposure, so she can seek immediate medical attention if needed.   Furthermore, the employer should ensure that the workplace is well-ventilated and that safety guidelines are strictly followed to minimize the risk of exposure to toxic substances.

The most appropriate pharmacotherapies to initiate in this case would be a beta-blocker and spironolactone.  This patient's presentation of abdominal distention, a fluid wave, and a history of alcohol use disorder and cirrhosis is consistent with ascites due to portal hypertension. First-line treatment for ascites includes sodium restriction, diuretics (eg, furosemide, spironolactone), and large-volume paracentesis for those with tense ascites. Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist, is the preferred initial diuretic because it addresses the secondary hyperaldosteronism that is common in cirrhosis. Furosemide is often added to enhance natriuresis and to counteract the potassium-sparing effects of spironolactone.  In addition to managing ascites, it is also important to prevent further complications of portal hypertension, such as variceal bleeding. Nonselective beta-blockers (eg, propranolol, nadolol) reduce portal pressure by decreasing cardiac output (beta1 effect) and causing splanchnic vasoconstriction (beta2 effect). They are used for primary and secondary prevention of variceal bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. Therefore, this patient should also be started on a nonselective beta-blocker.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)  The patient's presentation of severe epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and elevated serum amylase is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are gallstones and alcohol. However, this patient's history of moderate alcohol intake and significantly elevated triglycerides (>1000 mg/dL) suggest that hypertriglyceridemia is the likely etiology in this case. Hypertriglyceridemia can cause acute pancreatitis when levels exceed 1000 mg/dL.   Initial management of acute pancreatitis includes aggressive hydration, pain control, and management of any identified etiology. In the case of hypertriglyceridemia-induced pancreatitis, the goal is to lower triglycerides to <500 mg/dL to reduce the risk of ongoing pancreatitis. This is initially attempted with dietary fat restriction and fibrates. However, if triglycerides remain >1000 mg/dL despite these measures, or if the patient has severe pancreatitis (eg, organ failure, necrosis), therapeutic plasma exchange should be performed.   ERCP is not the appropriate next step in this case because it is primarily used in the management of gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis or ongoing biliary obstruction, which is not suggested by this patient's presentation and laboratory results.

The most appropriate initial step in management is to administer thiamine.  The patient's presentation of disorientation, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction (unable to cooperate with ocular examination) is suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, a condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. This condition is most commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to poor nutritional intake, but can also be seen in conditions with poor absorption of nutrients. Thiamine is a cofactor for several key enzymes in the brain. When thiamine levels are low, it leads to a decrease in synthesis of neurotransmitters, cerebral lactic acidosis, and breakdown of the blood-brain barrier.   The initial management of suspected Wernicke encephalopathy is administration of thiamine to prevent progression of the disease. Thiamine should be given before any glucose-containing fluids because glucose metabolism consumes thiamine and can precipitate or worsen Wernicke encephalopathy in a thiamine-deficient patient.

The best approach to prevent a similar adverse event in the future is to ensure that DVT prophylaxis is initiated perioperatively for patients who are at high risk. This can include pharmacological methods such as administering anticoagulants (like heparin or low molecular weight heparin), or mechanical methods such as graduated compression stockings or intermittent pneumatic compression devices. In this case, the patient was at high risk due to her age, cancer diagnosis, and recent surgery, all of which are known risk factors for DVT. Therefore, DVT prophylaxis should have been initiated. Regular risk assessment for DVT in hospitalized patients can also help in early detection and prevention.

The incidence of myocardial infarction in the group that received aspirin was 1.2%, compared to 2.2% in the group that received a placebo. This indicates that aspirin has a protective effect against myocardial infarction. However, it's important to note that these results are specific to the population studied (male physicians with no history of coronary artery disease) and may not be generalizable to other populations.

The most appropriate course of action for the circulating nurse is to immediately bring the discrepancy to the attention of the surgeon. The most appropriate next step in management would be to start broad-spectrum antibiotics.   The patient's presentation is suggestive of severe pneumonia, possibly leading to septic shock, given his low blood pressure, high heart rate, and high respiratory rate. His history of a chronic cough, recent pneumonia, and smoking further support this diagnosis. The chest x-ray showing diffuse alveolar infiltrates bilaterally is also consistent with pneumonia.   In such a case, it is crucial to start broad-spectrum antibiotics as soon as possible to cover for both typical and atypical pathogens. This is because the mortality rate for severe pneumonia and septic shock is high, and early antibiotic treatment has been shown to improve outcomes. The choice of antibiotics can be adjusted later based on the patient's response to treatment and any microbiological findings.   In addition to antibiotics, the patient should continue to receive supportive care, including oxygenation and ventilation, fluid resuscitation, and close monitoring of vital signs and organ function.

The most appropriate initial step in management is to administer activated charcoal.   This patient's sudden onset of confusion, sweating, pallor, dilated pupils, and flushed skin after an apparent ingestion of a large amount of imipramine is suggestive of a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose. TCAs are highly toxic in overdose. Symptoms can occur within 30 minutes and include anticholinergic symptoms (eg, dilated pupils, flushed skin, intestinal ileus), cardiac toxicity (eg, tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypotension), and central nervous system effects (eg, confusion, seizures, coma).   Activated charcoal is a form of carbon that has small, low-volume pores. These pores help increase the surface area available for adsorption or chemical reactions, which are key to its ability to absorb toxins. It is most effective when administered within 1 hour of ingestion. Therefore, in a case of suspected TCA overdose, after ensuring an adequate airway and establishing intravenous access, the next step should be administration of activated charcoal to limit drug absorption.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be an abdominal ultrasound.   This patient's family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), history of smoking, and age put him at increased risk for AAA. The presence of a midepigastric bruit could also be indicative of an AAA. An abdominal ultrasound is the screening test of choice for AAA because it is noninvasive, highly sensitive and specific, and relatively inexpensive. If an AAA is detected, the size and rate of growth can be monitored with serial ultrasounds, and surgical repair can be considered if the aneurysm is large or growing rapidly.

The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform a peripheral blood smear and reticulocyte count.   The patient's symptoms of fatigue, low back pain, decreased appetite, and weight loss, along with the physical examination finding of pale conjunctivae and laboratory findings of a low hematocrit and high mean corpuscular volume (MCV), suggest the possibility of anemia, specifically macrocytic anemia given the high MCV.   A peripheral blood smear and reticulocyte count can help confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of the anemia. The peripheral blood smear can show the size and shape of red blood cells, which can help identify the type of anemia. The reticulocyte count can indicate whether the bone marrow is producing red blood cells at an appropriate rate.   The mild osteopenia seen on the X-rays of the lumbosacral spine could be a separate issue related to age, or it could be related to the potential anemia if it is due to a condition that affects bone marrow function.

This patient's diagnosis puts her at risk for osteoporosis.
